note: Early and influential theory includes earlier works in an expanded definition of the novel; especially telling, though largely negative, account of the Greek romances.
title: The Dialogic Imagination: Four Essays

note: Excellent anthology on medieval and Renaissance forms of romance.
title: Romance: Generic Transformation from Chrétien de Troyes to Cervantes

note: One of the first, and most important, considerations of “genre literature.”
title: Adventure, Mystery and Romance: Formula Stories as Art and Popular Culture

note: Key argument about the marginalization of romance in literary history; emphasizes continuities between earlier forms and the later novel.
title: The True Story of the Novel

note: Central structuralist theory of romance as enduring mode.
title: Anatomy of Criticism

note: Expanded transhistorical consideration of romance as the “structural core of all fiction.”
title: The Secular Scripture: A Study of the Structure of Romance
The Cambridge Companion to Medieval Romance
Essential anthology by some of the most influential contemporary scholars of medieval romance; serves both as an introduction and as a sophisticated guide to further study

container-title: The Political Unconscious: Narrative as a Socially Symbolic Act
note: Central Marxist argument for reading genre – in this case, medieval romance – in its historical context and as a “social contract” between writers and readers.
title: Magical Narratives: On the Dialectical Use of Genre Criticism

note: 132 further reading [A transhistorical introduction to the “continuum” of narrative modes in fiction.
title: Novel and Romance: The Odyssey to Tom Jones

note: Groundbreaking deconstructive and transhistorical study of the way romance functions within texts, with an emphasis on the Renaissance.
title: Inescapable Romance: Studies in the Poetics of a Mode

note: Important study of modern romance novels and their readers, based on an ethnographic model.
title: Reading the Romance: Women, Patriarchy, and Popular Literature, Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press

note: Excellent introduction to romance in the classical world.
title: The Form of Greek Romance

note: Essential anthology on “ancient fiction,” including both theoretical discussions and connections to later periods.
title: The Search for the Ancient Novel

note: Exhaustive survey of Renaissance theories and literary quarrels about romance, especially in the second volume.
title: A History of Literary Criticism in the Italian Renaissance

note: Essential anthology of eighteenth-century criticism on the two categories, collected from prefaces, periodicals, letters, etc.
title: Novel and Romance, 1700–1800: A Documentary Record
